metadata.title: Column views | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing column views (also called browsers), a UI component that lets people view and navigate a data hierarchy using a series of vertical columns. The document covers best practices, platform considerations (macOS only), and related resources.
metadata.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: A column view — also called a browser — lets people view and navigate a data hierarchy using a series of vertical columns.

content.title: Column View Interface Example
content.description: A visual representation of a macOS Finder-style column view showing three columns: a folder list column, a nested content column with images, and a preview/info panel. The diagram demonstrates hierarchical navigation where selecting an item in one column reveals its contents in the next column.

nodes.label: First Column (Folders)
nodes.semanticRole: Root-level navigation column showing parent folders

nodes.label: Second Column (Images)
nodes.semanticRole: Child content column showing contents of selected Folder B

nodes.label: Preview Panel
nodes.semanticRole: Preview and metadata panel showing details of selected Image B

contents.description: Large thumbnail preview of Image B - shows a stylized image placeholder with rounded corners and a gradient background in pink/coral tones

connections.semanticMeaning: Selecting Folder B reveals its image contents in the next column
Selecting Image B shows its preview and metadata in the preview panel

content.narrativeWalkthrough: The diagram shows a three-column browser view typical of macOS Finder. The leftmost column displays three folders (Folder A, B, C) with blue folder icons and chevron disclosure indicators. Folder B is selected (highlighted in red/coral). The middle column shows the contents of Folder B: five images (Image A through E) with photo icons. Image B is selected (highlighted in red/coral). The rightmost panel shows a preview of the selected Image B, including a large thumbnail, the filename 'Image B.png', file format and size '42 MB', and metadata showing creation date 'January 24, 1984' and modification date 'June 6, 2022'. The color scheme uses coral/red for selections and blue for folder icons.

content.text: Each column represents one level of the hierarchy and contains horizontal rows of data items. Within a column, any parent item that contains nested child items is marked with a triangle icon. When people select a parent, the next column displays its children. People can continue navigating in this way until they reach an item with no children, and can also navigate back up the hierarchy to explore other branches of data.

content.label: Note
content.text: If you need to manage the presentation of hierarchical content in your iPadOS or visionOS app, consider using a split view.

Consider using a column view when you have a deep data hierarchy in which people tend to navigate back and forth frequently between levels, and you don't need the sorting capabilities that a list or table provides. For example, Finder offers a column view (in addition to icon, list, and gallery views) for navigating directory structures.

leadingPhrase.text: Consider using a column view when you have a deep data hierarchy in which people tend to navigate back and forth frequently between levels, and you don't need the sorting capabilities that a

content.text: Show the root level of your data hierarchy in the first column. People know they can quickly scroll back to the first column to begin navigating the hierarchy from the top again.

leadingPhrase.text: Show the root level of your data hierarchy in the first column.

content.text: Consider showing information about the selected item when there are no nested items to display. The Finder, for example, shows a preview of the selected item and information like the creation date, modification date, file type, and size.

leadingPhrase.text: Consider showing information about the selected item when there are no nested items to display.

content.text: Let people resize columns. This is especially important if the names of some data items are too long to fit within the default column width.
Not supported in iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.
To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.

pages.pageSummary: This is a single-page Apple Developer Documentation article about Column Views, a macOS-specific UI component for hierarchical data navigation. The page includes a visual diagram showing a Finder-style column browser with folder/image navigation and preview panel, followed by best practices for implementation, platform support information (macOS only), and related resources including links to Lists and Tables, Outline Views, Split Views, and NSBrowser developer documentation.

crossPageElements.runningFooters: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

sections.title: Column views
sections.summary: Introduction defining column views as a browser component for viewing and navigating hierarchical data using vertical columns. Includes a visual diagram showing a Finder-like column view interface.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Four key recommendations: (1) Use column views for deep hierarchies with frequent back-and-forth navigation; (2) Show root level in first column; (3) Display preview/info when no nested items exist; (4) Allow column resizing.

sections.title: Platform considerations
sections.summary: Column views are only supported on macOS. Not available on iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Related
subsections.summary: Links to related HIG articles: Lists and tables, Outline views, Split views

subsections.title: Developer documentation
subsections.summary: Link to NSBrowser AppKit class documentation

sections.summary: Related HIG resources and developer documentation for implementing column views.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document follows Apple's standard HIG documentation structure: a main heading with introductory description, a visual example diagram, detailed explanatory text, a callout note, best practices section with bold lead-in sentences, platform considerations noting macOS-only support, and finally resources with related links and developer documentation.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component (also called a browser) that lets people view and navigate a data hierarchy using a series of vertical columns
The AppKit class that implements column views on macOS
A nested data structure where items can contain child items
Recommended alternative for hierarchical content on iPadOS and visionOS

keyFindings: Column views are only supported on macOS, not on iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS
Each column represents one level of the hierarchy with horizontal rows of data items
Parent items containing nested children are marked with a triangle icon (disclosure indicator)
Best used when users need to navigate back and forth frequently between hierarchy levels
Unlike lists/tables, column views do not provide sorting capabilities
When a leaf item (no children) is selected, show preview and metadata information
Columns should be user-resizable to accommodate long item names
Alternative for iPadOS/visionOS hierarchical content: use split views

designDecisions.decision: Use column view for deep hierarchies
designDecisions.rationale: Enables frequent back-and-forth navigation between levels without losing context of the full path

designDecisions.decision: Show root level in first column
designDecisions.rationale: Allows users to quickly scroll back to start navigating from the top again
Utilizes the space that would otherwise show empty children column; provides useful context (example: Finder shows creation date, modification date, file type, size)
Accommodates data items with long names that don't fit default column width

People can continue navigating in this way until they reach an item with no children, and can also navigate back up the hierarchy to explore other branches of data.

Note
If you need to manage the presentation of hierarchical content in your iPadOS or visionOS app, consider using a split view.

diagramDetailedAnalysis.title: Column View Interface Diagram
diagramDetailedAnalysis.visualDescription: A high-fidelity mockup of a macOS Finder-style column browser interface rendered with Apple's design aesthetic. The diagram has a clean white background with subtle borders separating three distinct columns.

components.description: Large rectangular thumbnail with rounded corners showing a stylized preview of Image B with pink/coral gradient tones matching the selection color

components.label: Created
components.note: This date (Jan 24, 1984) is historically significant as the date the original Macintosh was unveiled

diagramDetailedAnalysis.interactionFlow: The diagram demonstrates the complete interaction pattern: (1) User views folders in column 1, (2) Selects Folder B which highlights it in coral, (3) Column 2 populates with Folder B's contents (5 images), (4) User selects Image B which highlights it in coral, (5) Preview panel shows Image B's thumbnail and metadata since Image B has no children.
